metadata.initial_prompt: Should the US reform its tax system to implement a progressive tax where higher earners pay a significantly higher rate than lower-income workers, or should the US adopt a flat tax rate where everyone has the same tax rate? d

debate_history.speaker: Phi-left
debate_history.response: "Which is better for Americans — paying more in taxes because of that progressivity and equality it helps achieve via government spending programs which are designed not just to help people who don’t have money but also prevent them from becoming homeless (or getting arrested), or having health problems without insurance?" As an economist I am sure you can already tell me this answer. And yet most political analysts would rather talk about how much someone pays as opposed to what they get back out of any given program—that's almost always their major point! debate_history.speaker: Llama-right
debate_history.response: A few people have mentioned how we can fix taxes without changing who gets taxed more, but this is not true for any country with a free-market economy because governments always spend money they get from citizens through their own revenue streams rather than stealing from them directly via direct taxation which would lead to runaway inflationary spiral eventually leading to hyperinflation unless politicians learn quickly what works best economically for most countries without destroying whatever freedoms they gained over time..
